content:
In March 2021, Veritas published an advisory reporting three critical vulnerabilities in Veritas Backup Exec 16.x, 20.x and 21.x.   
On September 23, 2022, a METASPLOIT module was released which exploits these vulnerabilities and creates a session which the threat actor can use to interact with the victim system.   
On October 22, 2022, Mandiant first observed exploitation of the Veritas vulnerabilities in the wild.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text mentions that a METASPLOIT module was released which exploits vulnerabilities, indicating a process-to-process relationship where the module exploits the vulnerabilities.   [Relationships]: <process:METASPLOIT module,exploits,process:Veritas Backup Exec 16.x, 20.x and 21.x vulnerabilities>. 
2. [CoT]: The text states that the module creates a session that the threat actor can use, showing a process-to-process relationship where the module creates a session.   [Relationships]: <process:METASPLOIT module,creates,socket:session>. 
3. [CoT]: The text describes Mandiant observing exploitation of the Veritas vulnerabilities in the wild, indicating a process-to-process relationship where Mandiant observes the exploitation.   [Relationships]: <process:Mandiant,observes,process:exploitation of the Veritas vulnerabilities>.

content: In late 2022, UNC4466 gained access to an internetexposed Windows server, running Veritas Backup Exec version 21.0 using the Metasploit module \`exploit/multi/veritas/beagent_sha_auth_rce\`. Shortly after, the Metasploit persistence module was invoked to maintain persistent access to the system for the remainder of this intrusion.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that UNC4466 gained access to the Windows server, indicating a process-to-process relationship where UNC4466 is the process gaining access to the Windows server process.   [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,gained access to,process:Windows server>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that the Metasploit persistence module was invoked to maintain access to the system, showing a process-to-process relationship where Metasploit persistence module is the process invoking other processes for maintenance.   [Relationships]: <process:Metasploit persistence module,invoked to maintain,persisten

content:
After gaining access to the Veritas Backup Exec server, UNC4466 used Internet Explorer, the browser installed by default on older Windows systems, to download Famatech's Advanced IP Scanner from its website, hxxps://download.advanced-ipscanner[.]com. This tool is capable of scanning individual IP addresses or IP address ranges for open ports, and returns hostnames, operating system and hardware manufacturer information. 
UNC4466 also made use of ADRecon to gather network, account, and host information in the victim's environment. When executed by a privileged domain account, ADRecon generates several reports about the Active Directory environment, including the Trusts, Sites, Subnets, password policies, user and computer account listings. These reports can be generated in a variety of formats, including CSV, XML, JSON, and HTML.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: UNC4466 used Internet Explorer to download a file from the specified URL. [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,used,process:Internet Explorer>. 
2. [CoT]: UNC4466 downloaded a file from the URL https://download.advanced-ipscanner[.]com. [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,downloaded,socket:hxxps://download.advanced-ipscanner[.]com>. 
3. [CoT]: UNC4466 used ADRecon to gather information. [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,used,process:ADRecon>. 
4. [CoT]: ADRecon generated reports about the Active Directory environment. [Relationships]: <process:ADRecon,generated,file:reports>.

content: UNC4466 leveraged SOCKS5 tunneling to communicate with compromised systems in the victim network. This technique is typically used to evade network defenses or other preventative network controls. Two separate tools were deployed to execute this technique, LIGOLO and REVSOCKS.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that UNC4466 leveraged SOCKS5 tunneling to communicate, indicating a process-to-socket relationship where UNC4466 is the process and SOCKS5 tunneling is the socket.   [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,leveraged,socket:SOCKS5 tunneling>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that LIGOLO was deployed to execute this technique, showing a process-to-process relationship where UNC4466 (the attacker process) deployed LIGOLO (another process).   [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,deployed,process:LIGOLO>. 
3. [CoT]: Similarly, the text states that REVSOCKS was deployed by UNC4466, indicating another process-to-process relationship where UNC4466 deployed REVSOCKS.   [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,deployed,process:REVSOCKS>. 
4. [CoT]: The text describes REVSOCKS as a tool that uses SOCKS5 tunneling, establishing a process-to-socket relationship where REVSOCKS (the process) uses SOCKS5 tunneling (the socket).   [Relationships]: <process:REVSOCKS,uses,socket:SOCKS5 tunneling>.

content:
The threat actor utilized multiple credential access tools, including Mimikatz, LaZagne and Nanodump to gather clear-text credentials and credential material. 
In November 2022, UNC4466 utilized the MIMIKATZ Security Support Provider injection module (\`MISC::MemSSP\`). This module collects credentials in clear text as they are used, by manipulating the Local Security Authority Server Service (LSASS) on victim systems. This module creates a file named \`C:\Windows\System32\mimilsa.log\`. 
mimikatz # privilege::debug   
Privilege '20" OK   
mimikatz # MISC::MemSSP   
Injected 
[Nanodump] was also used to dump LSASS memory. Like the examples shown on Helpsystems' GitHub page, the output file specified was a file in the \`C:\Windows\Temp\` directory.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that Mimikatz was used to manipulate the LSASS process, indicating a process-to-process relationship. [Relationships]: <process:Mimikatz,manipulate,process:LSASS>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that Mimikatz created a file named 'C:\Windows\System32\mimilsa.log', indicating a process-to-file relationship. [Relationships]: <process:Mimikatz,create,file:C:\Windows\System32\mimilsa.log>. 
3. [CoT]: The text states that Nanodump was used to dump LSASS memory, indicating a process-to-process relationship. [Relationships]: <process:Nanodump,dump,process:LSASS>. 
4. [CoT]: The text mentions that the output file specified was a file in the 'C:\Windows\Temp\ directory, indicating a process-to-file relationship. [Relationships]: <process:Nanodump,dump,file:C:\Windows\Temp\ directory>.

content: UNC4466 made use of BITS transfers (using the Start-BitsTransfer PowerShell cmdlet) to download various resources to the staging directory c:\ProgramData\`. Using this technique, SOCKS5 tunneling tools, REVSOCKS and LIGOLO were downloaded from their official GitHub repositories.
relationship: 1. [CoT]: The text states that UNC4466 used the Start-BitsTransfer PowerShell cmdlet to download resources, which were later identified as SOCKS5 tunneling tools (REVSOCKS and LIGOLO) from GitHub repositories.   [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,using,process:Start-BitsTransfer>.

content: UNC4466 deploys the Rust-based ALPHV ransomware. In Late 2022, UNC4466 added immediate tasks to the default domain policy. These tasks were configured to perform actions which disabled security software, downloaded the ALPHV encryptor, then execute it.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that UNC4466 deploys the Rust-based ALPHV ransomware, indicating a process-to-process relationship where UNC4466 is the source process and ALPHV ransomware is the target process.   [Relationships]: <process:UNC4466,deploys,process:ALPHV ransomware>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that tasks were configured to download the ALPHV encryptor, showing a process-to-file relationship where the tasks (process) download the ALPHV encryptor (file).   [Relationships]: <process:tasks,downloads,file:ALPHV encryptor>. 
3. [CoT]: The text describes that tasks were configured to execute the ALPHV encryptor, indicating a process-to-process relationship where the tasks (process) execute the ALPHV encryptor (process).   [Relationships]: <process:tasks,executes,process:ALPHV encryptor>.
